name: iron pellet production | iron pellet | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/21050/documentation

This dataset represents iron pellet production in India. ;Pellets are primarily used in blast furnaces and are also used in DR-plants. Occasionally pellets are used;in the steel process.;Pellets are stored in bunkers before charging to the blast furnace.;The mixture of iron bearing materials (iron ore rubble, sinter and/or pellets) and additives (flux material);are known collectively as the "burden". 

After iron ore mining and beneficiation, the next step in steel manufacturing is iron pellet production.

After iron ore mining and beneficiation, the next step is iron pellet production. This activity ends at iron pelletization plant.The iron pellets are sent to Blast Furnace or Corex for hot metal and pig iron production.
category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/241:Manufacture of basic iron and steel/2410:Manufacture of basic iron and steel

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data for this dataset was provided for the year April 2014- March 2015.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Inputs related to integrated steel plants in India
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Pellets are primarily used in blast furnaces and are also used in DR-plants. Occasionally pellets are used;in the steel process.;Pellets are stored in bunkers before charging to the blast furnace.;The mixture of iron bearing materials (iron ore rubble, sinter and/or pellets) and additives (flux material);are known collectively as the "burden". The burden and the accompanying coke are charged into the top;of the furnace either via skips or mechanical conveyor belts. It enters into the furnace via a sealed;charging system, which isolates the furnace gases from the atmosphere.;As for all blast furnace material (coke, sinter, pellets and lump ore) a final screening takes place at the;blast furnace site. Undersize pellets can be recycled.;The pellets for the BOS plant are stored in bunkers. Transport in the BOS plant can take place by truck or;conveyor belt.                            Iron ore pellets are spheres of typically 6–16 mm (0.24–0.63 in) to be used as raw material for blast furnaces. They typically contain 67%-72% Fe and various additional material adjusting the chemical composition and the metallurgic properties of the pellets.Typically limestone, dolostone and olivine is added and Bentonite is used as binder.;;The process of pelletizing combines mixing of the raw material, forming the pellet and a thermal treatment baking the soft raw pellet to hard spheres. The raw material is rolled into a ball, then fired in a kiln to sinter the particles into a hard sphere.;;The configuration of iron ore pellets as packed spheres in the blast furnace allows air to flow between the pellets, decreasing the resistance to the air that flows up through the layers of material during the smelting. The configuration of iron ore powder in a blast furnace is more tightly-packed and restricts the air flow. This is the reason that iron ore is preferred in the form of pellets rather than in the form of finer particles.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Certain emissions to air have been extrapolated from GLO dataset.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data from three production plants in India with total iron pellet production capacity of 1,25,07,215 tonnes per year.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=GLO
This dataset represents iron pellet production in India. 
Pellets are primarily used in blast furnaces and are also used in DR-plants. Occasionally pellets are used
in the steel process.
Pellets are stored in bunkers before charging to the blast furnace.
The mixture of iron bearing materials (iron ore rubble, sinter and/or pellets) and additives (flux material)
are known collectively as the "burden".

exchanges.description: Data from ecoinvent dataset for "iron pellet production, GLO" accessed through ecoeditor on 20170815

Emissions are calculated based on the following formula: 

Sum of - 

amount of coke used by process * 0.031 * 44.01/12.01

amount of coal used by process * 0.732 * 44.01/12.01

amount of BF gas used by process * 0.0803 * 44.01/12.01

amount of diesel used by process * 0.865 * 44.01/12.01
Data received from integrated steel plants in India.
